Yet its liberals who dont believe in science, ironic huh.  You know like the science that shows life begins at conception
No science shows that.
actually it does, you truly should get an education.  Being willfully IGN0RANT is a disgusting liberal thing.

I teach anatomy, among other things.
The embryology textbook I use puts it this way: "Human development begins at conception." When a human life begins is a matter of philosophy, not science. Possibilities include conception, implantation, a detectable heartbeat, viability, and birth. All of those are consistent with science (though the heartbeat one is silly), and all are matters of opinion.

And before you tell people to get an education (I have a PhD in anthropology) or accuse them of being liberal (I lean conservative), perhaps you should think more deeply.

NONSENSE.  I believe the science and the scientists who hold this view.  Why dont you? I dont believe you for a second. "A sample of 5,502 biologists from 1,058 academic institutions assessed statements representing the biological view ‘a human’s life begins at fertilization’." "Overall, 95% of all biologists affirmed the biological view that a human's life begins at fertilization (5212 out of 5502)."
I'm fine with that view. But it is still an opinion. Philosophers have struggled with this question for centuries. It is not a scientific question. Where did you get your data?

Its science.  With modern technology they can actually SEE  the fetus growing.  You really should get into the 21st century.  I doubt if you are a teacher, if you are you are cheating them out of a real education.  "Steven Andrew Jacobs PHd
University of Chicago - Department of Comparative Human Development; Northwestern Prizker School of Law
Date Written: July 25, 2018

Yes, I watched both of my sons develop in the womb, both in the twentieth century. Your timeline is a bit off.
You are missing the point. All the technology in the world cannot answer a subjective philosophical question.
You seem like a sincere person, so let me give you an analogy. I am a professor of anthropology who studies human evolution. We have a fossil record that goes back 6 million years of hominin evolution. We know that our own modern species arose only' about 100,000 years ago. Is that when we became human, or could our predecessors be called 'human' as well? That is a subjective question, just like when a 'human' life begins.

once again science denier - its SCIENCE not philosophy.  You are not  a professor, your mind is too closed to be allowed to teach.  Your deflection and deversion is REJECTED.   I pray every day that people like you are not teachers, you only have one view and you are unable to open your mind to facts or new data.  Go away klown, I have no more time for you

context: I have my own theory about the Big Bang. Before the big bang there was  no space. There was only the singularity that contained massive energy in the most basic form. With no where to go it eventually exploded. The singularity or black hole was broken up into a trillion or more pieces and these are what we call super massive black holes that are at the center of each galaxy. And the rest of the energy form hydrogen and stars, many going super nova creating all the elements that formed planets. All the stars and planets grouped together to their closest super massive black holes creating galaxy's. The super massive black holes that are in the center of each galaxy exist in space now, and if they consume too much material, can release the material as energy, and this is what they call an Active super massive black hole. The question is can this newly released basic energy from active black holes form into hydrogen. Or did it take the power of the original big bang to do that.
